This one actually is necessary: it's only BasicHack that registers itself as a listener upon `onEnable`
goddamnit i hate hacks

Needs an `onDisable` override here to remove this listener, then the `if(!config.isEnabled()) return;` checks are not necessary since the event will only ever be called when the hack is enabled, because the listeners will only ever be registered upon hack enable.
Why?
SoundTech asked to add `type` because he wants to add others (e.g radius limit) in the future
Making it an enum would mean adding yet another useless for anything else class. Can't make it a subclass because it needs to be accessed from different packages.
Is a type really necessary? Just have a sealed interface and then [switch-instanceof](https://openjdk.org/jeps/441) it.

I do not understand the concern with adding another class, even if it was necessary which I don't think it is? Would defining a public enum in an already existing class not work just fine?

In any case, using a String is quite bad form as:
1. It can be anything - easy for bugs to sneak in
2. Finding out what it can be is near impossible

Enums fix these issues. 

BTW, I recently did this exact refactoring: https://github.com/Gjum/SnitchMod/commit/4babc246830f8667d2feb590ea298d02d3c8f7c2#diff-74f85b746999fee67db379e6128c815f7e0a3d0f1f5cb0d4e1a4471e2a20c8b6R12

Use [`HandlerList.unregisterAll(this);`](https://github.com/CivMC/Civ/blob/c6278bd01319bbf55c415113efd89ba3cad61f2a/plugins/simpleadminhacks-paper/src/main/java/com/programmerdan/minecraft/simpleadminhacks/framework/BasicHack.java#L23), which is what BasicHack uses.
This shouldEnable() call is still unnecessary and will cause unexpected behaviour if something happens like the hack is disabled in the config, but then is enabled by a command.

This throwing is fine as it will disable the hack, which will be more visible to the administrator. Just printing the error like this will cause strange behaviour as the hack will still be enabled but not initialised properly.

Throwing is fine here as the exception will be handled and actually printed rather than discarded, so it's clearer what the problem actually is. See `org.bukkit.configuration.serialization.ConfigurationSerialization#deserializeViaMethod`

Not sure these work, iirc `.getItemMeta()` creates a duplicate meta, so any changes to it would then need to be saved back onto the item.

Yeah, I think that'd be a much better solution just because of the volume of stuff that items can have now that needs to be checked for and assigned. I put something together using Bukkit's inbuilt ItemStack serialization that works pretty well, as well as a command in SAH to quickly see what a serialized item should look like in a config.

Small thing: it's better to do `Component.text(" has left the game", NamedTextColor.YELLOW)` instead as then you aren't re-creating the component with the colour, but instead are colouring the original component. Just a small allocation optimisation.

nit: no need for the double indents here, the `) {` being on its own line means a single indent is fine

misleading formatting, the `&&` is on the same line as the previous check but applies to the whole statement; use one of these, depending on intent:

```
|| (acidMan.isPossibleAcidBlock(relativeBlock) && acidMan.isAcidOnSameGroup(reinforcement, relativeReinforcement))
```
or
```
|| acidMan.isPossibleAcidBlock(relativeBlock)
&& acidMan.isAcidOnSameGroup(reinforcement, relativeReinforcement)
```


also same nit as before: whole statement can be 1-indented

actually, shouldn't it just be
```
|| acidMan.isPossibleAcidBlock(relativeBlock)
|| acidMan.isAcidOnSameGroup(reinforcement, relativeReinforcement)
```
?

was this tested?

Just keep in mind this is a *global* toggle, so if someone hides banned players in their `/ep showall` window, then everyone else after that will also have banned players hidden. And when someone then unhides them, everyone after that will also see them.
contruct :]
Huh, didn't realise. Is there a better way to do it then?

You could do something similar to the `COOLDOWNS` map slightly above. Or you could make it a player setting and let people toggle it on or off without needing to run `/ep showall`, which might be preferred since it's a particularly taxing command to run. It'll also help with option persistence, as in, you don't need to open `/ep showall` and then re-open it with the toggle, doubling the strain on the server, to see what you want to see.

You can use executeUpdate here and checked if the number of updated rows was 0 or 1 to see if the insert was actually successful. Since you are using INSERT IGNORE you could be doing nothing (that is, trying to add a warp with the same name as an existing warp) and this method will still return true

```suggestion
                name VARCHAR(64) PRIMARY KEY,
```
UNIQUE and NOT NULL are implied by PRIMARY KEY

This config section needs some work, as it stands the config options are confusing and it's not clear that `skyBase` is added to `base`, and lacks the ability to disable subfeatures.

I would arrange it like this:

```yaml
  BetterRails:
    enabled: true
    baseSpeed: 12
    materials:
      COBBLESTONE: 8
      COPPER_BLOCK: 29
      EXPOSED_COPPER: 23
      WEATHERED_COPPER: 18
      OXIDIZED_COPPER: 14
    skyBonus:
      enabled: true
      bonus: 1
```

If sky materials are really needed to be different,

```yaml
  BetterRails:
    enabled: true
    speeds:
      - type: default
         baseSpeed: 12
         materials:
           COBBLESTONE: 8
           COPPER_BLOCK: 29
           EXPOSED_COPPER: 23
           WEATHERED_COPPER: 18
           OXIDIZED_COPPER: 14
      - type: sky
         baseSpeed: 13
         materials:
           COBBLESTONE: 9
           COPPER_BLOCK: 30
           EXPOSED_COPPER: 24
           WEATHERED_COPPER: 19
           OXIDIZED_COPPER: 15
```
This doesn't seem like it ignores transparent blocks, which it should. Otherwise stuff like glass and leaves would cause it to not reach full speed.
This is intentional, a bonus is provided if you can't protect your rails like that.

whats the point in checking the block type here? also doesn't this add another point where a blocklist needs to be maintained?

It's necessary to check the block type here because there is no `LogStripEvent` or equivalent, so the event needs to be inferred from a right-click block interaction involving a log and an axe. And while this switch will need to be maintained, the event handler is no longer vulnerable to collateral changes.
